boat.name: Stout
boat.full_description:
The requirements of the time were that vessels should be able to accomplish their work as a pilot under sail or engine power. A raw oil engine was therefore installed. After her service as a pilot boat she was sold to a person in Limhamn (outside Malmö) and was painted white.

She was rigged with only one mast, and is said to have had terrible sailing properties. After some time she was sold to Limhamns Sjöscoutkår (sea scouts), still with one mast but was painted black again.

Later she ended up with a captain from Norway, who understood that she needed her original ketch rig. He was also responsible for the glass fibre sheathing (this was done around 1974-75). Her home port was Stockholm during this time.

In 1990 she was bought by a sailmaker in Idrefjorden. He only kept her a short time and she was then bought by KFUK-KFUM:s Sjöscoutkår i Malmö (sea scouts) again. They made some repairs and changes to the interior and sailed her for several years.

From 1999 she was laid up on land, unfortunately without a cover. Wind and rain did some damage to the superstructure and the cockpit started to rot. She was a sad sight. The bowsprit had been broken and lay in pieces in a shed nearby.

She was gradually rebuilt between 2001-7 by Magnus Krampell, before he sold her.
boat.construction_details: Oak on oak with substantial GRP skin
boat.short_description: 'Stout' was built 1907 for the Royal Pilot Administration (Kungliga Lotsstyrelsen) for service in Öresound under sail or power propulsion. In a 'For sale' ad. in 2006, she was described as 'a little ship with plenty of character'.
